3. Process Hazard Analysis:  A formal study of the ammonia refrigeration system with management, safety, and maintenance personnel was conducted using the Checklist method to evaluate the potential hazards of the system.  A recommendation summary is used to track completion of all recommendations. 

4. Operating Procedures:  Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) have been developed and implemented to ensure safe operation of the refrigeration system.  SOPs are annually re-certified by the Chief Engineer or qualified designee.   

5. Training:  The Facility Maintenance Manager and Refrigeration Technicians are trained on all aspects of the ammonia system and are required to attend various types of training relative to the ammonia system and/or their respective duties and tasks.  All refrigeration technicians employees are incentivized to achieve either RETA CARO/CIRO certification.

6. Contractors:  Contractors are screened and evaluated prior to performing work on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.  Contractors receive documented training on the safety and hazards of the system and are required to meet with the Facility Maintenance Manager prior to working on the system.  

7. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):  A PSSR includes policy and procedures as well as a checklist to ensure that all documents relating to the PSSR are collected, reviewed and retained.  Each Engineer is trained on the PSSR.     

8. Mechanical Integrity:  Mechanical Integrity policy and procedures have been implemented at this facility.  Mechanical Integrity Inspections are performed annually. 

9. Hot Work Permits:  A Hot Work Permit program is in place at this facility which requires a hot work permit form to be completed prior to working on or near the process. 

10. Management of Change (MOC):  A MOC system has been implemented.  Changes to the process are completed using the Management of Change p

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM-ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Lineage Logistics: Grand Forks, North Dakota facility is a public refrigerated warehouse. The facility maintains freezer storage spaces of nearly 4 million cubic ft. which is used to store perishable products.  Storage areas at the facility operate at 0°F to -5°F.  The facility has nine truck loading and unloading spots and five railcar spots to facilitate the transportation of products.  A mechanical refrigeration system, utilizing anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant, is used to maintain desired temperatures.  The refrigeration system operates in a closed loop; the ammonia is not mixed with other chemicals.

FACILITY CONSTRUCTION:  The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with mechanical and building codes in effect at the time of the various phases of construction.  These codes outline requirements for the safe installation and operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.

SAFETY FEATURES:  The ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Safeties include, but are not limited to: pressure relief valves, stop valves, ammonia detectors, a computerized refrigeration monitoring and control system, as well as trained and experienced operators.  Much of the safety associated with the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern its operation.   For example, the facility operates in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68). 

MANAGEMENT COMMITMENT TO SAFETY:  Lineage Logistics has a long standing commitment to worker, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system. It is Lineage Logistics policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.
T

he Program 3 at Lineage Logistics - Grand Forks is a facility run program with continuous support from Lineage Logistics - Safety and Compliance Department that includes Process Safety Management (PSM) Compliance and Environmental Health and Safety (EHS) Compliance.
Management is committed to providing all necessary resources to ensure that all elements within the regulations are adhered to.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM:  A Management System has been developed to ensure that all elements of the PSM and RMP regulations are implemented.   Each person outlined in the responsibilities section of the management system is assigned various tasks and is expected to participate in the development and implementation of the programs.  
Various employees work as a team to ensure that:  
1. Employees participate in the implementation of the programs.
2. Process Safety Information: safety systems and refrigeration parameters were developed and are implemented
3. Employees participate in the Process Hazard Analysis, and recommendations are addressed in a timely manner.
4. Operating procedures are developed, implemented, and certified annually.
5. Appropriate training is provided to refrigeration technician employees.
6. Contractors are qualified to work on or near the refrigeration system and trained on potential hazards associated with the system.
7. Pre-Startup Safety Reviews are performed on all new and modified systems prior to placing ammonia into the system.
8. Mechanical Integrity Inspections are performed as required.  All deficiencies are noted and addressed in a timely manner.
9. A Hot Work program is implemented and all persons affected by the hot work are aware of potential hazards.
10. A Management of Change program is in place, and the appropriate documentation is completed prior to the implementation of changes. 
11. Incident Investigations are performed on accidental ammonia releases as well as near-misses.  Resolutions and corrective actions are documented. 
12. An Emergenc

y Action Plan is developed and employees trained on it.  The plan is reviewed and certified at least annually.
13. Compliance Audits are performed and recommendations are addressed in a timely manner.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:  There have been no reportable ammonia related accidents, incidents or releases at the facility during the past five years.  

EMERGENCY ACTION PROGRAM:  The facility has established an Emergency Action Plan.  The Plan explains what actions employees, contractor employees, and visitors are to take in the event of an emergency which include steps to take in the event of a fire, earthquake, tornado, etc. 
The Emergency Action Plan states that all employees shall: 
1. Initiate an evacuation by activating the public announcement (PA) system and/or two-way radios.
2. Notify the appropriate emergency responders. 
3. Assist in a safe and orderly evacuation. 
4. Gather at the designated assembly area(s) for a head count.  

The Emergency Action Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. 

PREVENTION PROGRAM 3:  
1. Employee Participation:  The Facility Maintenance Manager, Refrigeration Technicians and Management are actively involved in the development and implementation of PSM and RMP programs.  The FMM and refrigeration technicians gather process safety information, develop and implement operating procedures, qualify contractors, participate in the process hazard analysis, and the resolution of all PHA/compliance audit recommendations.  

2. Process Safety Information:  Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams have been developed, and all piping and major components of the ammonia refrigeration system have been identified.  Information has been gathered to enable employees to identify and understand the potential hazards of the system.  The process safety information includes the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia.   An ammonia inventory is collected and retained in the PSI Library.  Relief Valves are identified and lab

olicies and procedures. 

11. Incident Investigation:  All incidents and near-misses are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an incident investigation form.  Deficiencies noted during the de-briefing are addressed in a timely manner.

12. Emergency Planning and Response:  Lineage Logistics: Grand Forks employees do not actively respond to non-incidental ammonia releases. Thus, an Emergency Response Plan is not required.

13. Compliance Audits:  Audits are conducted every three years by an outside consultant to ensure that all elements are in compliance with PSM and RMP requirements.  

14. Five-Year Accident History:  No ammonia related incidents have occurred at this facility in the past five years.   

15. Description of plans to improve safety:  Continuous safety improvement is a key component of Lineage Logistics core values.  The Grand Forks facility plans to improve safety by developing our associates through training and education, encouraging our employees to identify hazards and assist in the abatement process, identifying new technologies and giving careful consideration to their implementation, and continually refining our PSM and RMP programs.
